post.description: On ingest, the document goes through a series of steps before it is ready for retrieval. Each step is reflected in the status of the document which can be one of [`pending`, `partitioning`, `partitioned`, `refined`, `chunked`, `indexed`, `summary_indexed`, `keyword_indexed`, `ready`, `failed`]. The document is available for retrieval once it is in ready state. The summary index step can take a few seconds. You can optionally use the document for retrieval once it is in `indexed` state. However the summary will only be available once the state has changed to `summary_indexed` or `ready`.

get.description: List all documents sorted by created_at in descending order. Results are paginated with a max limit of 100. When more documents are available, a `cursor` will be provided. Use the `cursor` parameter to retrieve the subsequent page.

parameters.name: cursor

schema.description: An opaque cursor for pagination
schema.title: Cursor

parameters.description: An opaque cursor for pagination

parameters.name: page_size

schema.description: The number of items per page (must be greater than 0 and less than or equal to 100)
schema.title: Page Size

parameters.description: The number of items per page (must be greater than 0 and less than or equal to 100)

parameters.name: filter

schema.description: The metadata search filter. Returns only items which match the filter. The following filter operators are supported: $eq - Equal to (number, string, boolean), $ne - Not equal to (number, string, boolean), $gt - Greater than (number), $gte - Greater than or equal to (number), $lt - Less than (number), $lte - Less than or equal to (number), $in - In array (string or number), $nin - Not in array (string or number). The operators can be combined with AND and OR. Read [Metadata & Filters guide](https://docs.ragie.ai/docs/metadata-filters) for more details and examples.
schema.title: Filter

parameters.description: The metadata search filter. Returns only items which match the filter. The following filter operators are supported: $eq - Equal to (number, string, boolean), $ne - Not equal to (number, string, boolean), $gt - Greater than (number), $gte - Greater than or equal to (number), $lt - Less than (number), $lte - Less than or equal to (number), $in - In array (string or number), $nin - Not in array (string or number). The operators can be combined with AND and OR. Read [Metadata & Filters guide](https://docs.ragie.ai/docs/metadata-filters) for more details and examples.

parameters.name: partition

schema.description: An optional partition to scope the request to. If omitted, accounts created after 1/9/2025 will have the request scoped to the default partition, while older accounts will have the request scoped to all partitions. Older accounts may opt in to strict partition scoping by contacting support@ragie.ai. Older accounts using the partitions feature are strongly recommended to scope the request to a partition.
schema.title: Partition

parameters.description: An optional partition to scope the request to. If omitted, accounts created after 1/9/2025 will have the request scoped to the default partition, while older accounts will have the request scoped to all partitions. Older accounts may opt in to strict partition scoping by contacting support@ragie.ai. Older accounts using the partitions feature are strongly recommended to scope the request to a partition.

post.description: Ingest a document as raw text. On ingest, the document goes through a series of steps before it is ready for retrieval. Each step is reflected in the status of the document which can be one of [`pending`, `partitioning`, `partitioned`, `refined`, `chunked`, `indexed`, `summary_indexed`, `keyword_indexed`, `ready`, `failed`]. The document is available for retrieval once it is in ready state. The summary index step can take a few seconds. You can optionally use the document for retrieval once it is in `indexed` state. However the summary will only be available once the state has changed to `summary_indexed` or `ready`.

Ingest a document from a publicly accessible URL. On ingest, the document goes through a series of steps before it is ready for retrieval. Each step is reflected in the status of the document which can be one of [`pending`, `partitioning`, `partitioned`, `refined`, `chunked`, `indexed`, `summary_indexed`, `keyword_indexed`, `ready`, `failed`]. The document is available for retrieval once it is in ready state. The summary index step can take a few seconds. You can optionally use the document for retrieval once it is in `indexed` state. However the summary will only be available once the state has changed to `summary_indexed` or `ready`. PDF files over 2000 pages are not supported in hi_res mode.

schema.description: The id of the document.
schema.title: Document Id

schema.description: An optional partition to scope the request to. Older accounts may opt in to strict partition scoping by contacting support@ragie.ai. Older accounts using the partitions feature are strongly recommended to scope the request to a partition.

Each step is reflected in the status of the document which can be one of [`pending`, `partitioning`, `partitioned`, `refined`, `chunked`, `indexed`, `summary_indexed`, `keyword_indexed`, `ready`, `failed`]. The document is available for retrieval once it is in ready state. The summary index step can take a few seconds. You can optionally use the document for retrieval once it is in `indexed` state. However the summary will only be available once the state has changed to `summary_indexed` or `ready`. PDF files over 2000 pages are not supported in hi_res mode.

get.description: List all document chunks sorted by index in ascending order. May be limited to a range of chunk indices with the `start_index` and `end_index` parameters. Documents created prior to 9/18/2024, which have not been updated since, have chunks which do not include an index and their index will be returned as -1. They will be sorted by their ID instead. Updating the document using the `Update Document File` or `Update Document Raw` endpoint will regenerate document chunks, including their index. Results are paginated with a max limit of 100. When more chunks are available, a `cursor` will be provided. Use the `cursor` parameter to retrieve the subsequent page.

parameters.name: document_id

schema.description: The id of the document.
schema.title: Document Id

parameters.description: The id of the document.

parameters.name: start_index

schema.description: The inclusive starting index of the chunk range to list. If omitted and `end_index` is present effectively limits results to at most one chunk matching `end_index`. If both `start_index` and `end_index` are omitted, results are not limited by index.
schema.title: Start Index

parameters.description: The inclusive starting index of the chunk range to list. If omitted and `end_index` is present effectively limits results to at most one chunk matching `end_index`. If both `start_index` and `end_index` are omitted, results are not limited by index.

parameters.name: end_index

schema.description: The inclusive ending index of the chunk range to list. If omitted and `start_index` is present effectively limits results to at most one chunk matching `start_index`. If both `start_index` and `end_index` are omitted, results are not limited by index.
schema.title: End Index

parameters.description: The inclusive ending index of the chunk range to list. If omitted and `start_index` is present effectively limits results to at most one chunk matching `start_index`. If both `start_index` and `end_index` are omitted, results are not limited by index.

schema.description: An opaque cursor for pagination

schema.description: The desired media type of the content to return described as a mime type. An error will be returned if the requested media type is not supported for the chunk's document type.

parameters.name: download

schema.description: Whether to return the content as a file download or a raw stream. If set to `true`, the content will be returned as a named file for download.

200.description: Returns the source content of the document chunk.

get.description: Get the content of a document. The `media_type` parameter can be used to request the content in a different format. When requesting as `application/json` additional metadata about the document will be included. If the original document contained content such as images or other non-textual media, this response will include a text description of that media instead of the original file data. Using mime types such as `audio/mpeg` or `video/mp4` will stream the file in a format that can be provided to an audio video player.

parameters.name: document_id

schema.description: The id of the document.
schema.title: Document Id

parameters.description: The id of the document.

parameters.name: media_type

schema.description: The desired media type of the content to return described as a mime type. An error will be returned if the requested media type is not supported for the document's type.
schema.title: Media Type

parameters.description: The desired media type of the content to return described as a mime type. An error will be returned if the requested media type is not supported for the document's type.

parameters.name: download

schema.description: Whether to return the content as a file download or a raw stream. If set to `true`, the content will be returned as a named file for download.

get.description: Get the source file of a document. The source file is the original file that was uploaded to create the document. If the document was created from a URL, the source file will be the content of the URL. If the document was created by a connection, the source file will vary based on the type of the connection. For example, a Google Drive connection will return the file that was synced from the Google Drive, while a SalesForce connection would return a JSON file of the data synced from SalesForce.

schema.description: The id of the document.

get.description: Get a LLM generated summary of the document. The summary is created when the document is first created or updated. Documents of types ['xls', 'xlsx', 'csv', 'json'] are not supported for summarization. Documents greater than 1M in token length are not supported. This feature is in beta and may change in the future.

post.description: Create a new instruction. Instructions are applied to documents as they are created or updated. The results of the instruction are stored as structured data in the schema defined by the `entity_schema` parameter. The `prompt` parameter is a natural language instruction which will be applied to documents. This feature is in beta and may change in the future.

schema.description: The ID of the instruction.

parameters.description: The ID of the instruction.

post.description: Creates a redirect url to redirect the user to when initializing an embedded connector.

get.description: List available connection source types like 'google_drive' and 'notion' along with their metadata

put.description: Enable or disable the connection. A disabled connection won't sync.
Updates a connections metadata or mode. These changes will be seen after the next sync.

get.description: Lists connection stats: total documents active documents, total active pages.

put.description: Sets limits on a connection. Limits can be set on the total number of pages a connection can sync. When the limit is reached, the connection will be disabled. Limit may be removed by setting it to `null`.

post.description: Schedules a connection to be deleted. You can choose to keep the files from the connection or delete them all. If you keep the files, they will no longer be associated to the connection. Deleting can take some time, so you will still see files for a bit after this is called.

schema.title: Response Delete Connection Connections  Connection Id  Delete Post

post.description: Schedules a connector to sync as soon as possible.

get.description: List all partitions sorted by name in ascending order. Results are paginated with a max limit of 100. When more partitions are available, a `cursor` will be provided. Use the `cursor` parameter to retrieve the subsequent page.

parameters.name: cursor

schema.description: An opaque cursor for pagination
schema.title: Cursor

parameters.description: An opaque cursor for pagination

parameters.name: page_size

schema.description: The number of items per page (must be greater than 0 and less than or equal to 100)
schema.title: Page Size

parameters.description: The number of items per page (must be greater than 0 and less than or equal to 100)

post.description: Create a new partition. Partitions are used to scope documents, connections, and instructions. Partitions must be lowercase alphanumeric and may only include the special characters `_` and `-`. A partition may also be created by creating a document in it. Limits for a partition may optionally be defined when creating.

get.description: Get a partition by its ID. Includes usage information such as the number of documents and pages hosted and processed. The partition's limits are also included.

delete.description: Deletes a partition and all of its associated data. This includes connections, documents, and partition specific instructions. This operation is irreversible.

schema.title: Response Delete Partition Partitions  Partition Id  Delete

post.description: Enables context-aware descriptions for a partition. This will allow the automatically generate a desccription for based on the documents in the partition.

delete.description: Disables context-aware descriptions for a partition. This will stop automatically generating descriptions for the partition.

put.description: Sets limits on a partition. Limits can be set on the total number of pages a partition can host and process. When the limit is reached, the partition will be disabled. A limit may be removed by setting it to `null`.

get.description: List all authenticators sorted by created_at in descending order. Results are paginated with a max limit of 100. When more authenticators are available, a `cursor` will be provided. Use the `cursor` parameter to retrieve the subsequent page.

parameters.name: cursor

schema.description: An opaque cursor for pagination
schema.title: Cursor

parameters.description: An opaque cursor for pagination

parameters.name: page_size

schema.description: The number of items per page (must be greater than 0 and less than or equal to 100)
schema.title: Page Size

parameters.description: The number of items per page (must be greater than 0 and less than or equal to 100)

post.description: Create a connector for a given authenticator. This requires credentials dependent on the provider. For google drive it is a refresh token.

delete.description: Delete an authenticator. This requires all connections created by that authenticator to be deleted first.

post.description: Create a response. This will generate an LLM or agentic response. At this time the only supported model is `deep-search`. Responses may be streamed or returned synchronously. The `retrieve` tool is currently the only supported tool, more tools will be added in the future. A single partition may be provided in the retrieve tool. If omitted the `default` partition is used.

get.description: Get a response by its ID. This will return the response and its status. If the response is still in progress, the status will be `in_progress`. If the response is completed, the status will be `completed`. If the response is failed, the status will be `failed`.

post.description: When events occur in Ragie such as a document being processed, we'll send this data to URLs that you can register in app. Learn more about webhooks in our docs: https://docs.ragie.ai/docs/webhooks.

evidence.title: Evidence
evidence.description: The evidence used to derive the answer.

other_resolved_question_ids.title: Other Resolved Question Ids
other_resolved_question_ids.description: A list of question ids that are no longer relevant to the current answer referenced by their IDs.

email.description: The email of the Dropbox account this is for

user_email.description: The email of the Salesforce account this is for

user_email.description: The email of the Sharepoint account this is for

user_email.description: The email of the Slack account this is for

name.title: Name
name.description: The unique name of your authenticator, used to identify it and distinguish it from others. This name must be unique. Attempting to reuse the same name will result in an error.

mode.title: Mode
mode.description: Partition strategy for the document. Different strategies exist for textual, audio and video file types and you can set the strategy you want for  each file type, or just for textual types.  For textual documents the options are `'hi_res'` or `'fast'`. When set to `'hi_res'`, images and tables will be extracted from the document. `'fast'` will only extract text. `'fast'` may be up to 20x faster than `'hi_res'`. `hi_res` is only applicable for Word documents, PDFs, Images, and PowerPoints. Images will always be processed in `hi_res`. If `hi_res` is set for an unsupported document type, it will be processed and billed in `fast` mode.  For audio files, the options are true or false. True if you want to process audio, false otherwise.          For video files, the options are `'audio_only'`, `'video_only'`, `'audio_video'`. `'audio_only'` will extract just the audio part of the video. `'video_only'` will similarly just extract the video part, ignoring audio. `'audio_video'` will extract both audio and video.  To process all media types at the highest quality, use `'all'`.  When you specify audio or video stategies, the format must be a JSON object. In this case, textual documents are denoted by the key "static". If you omit a key, that document type won't be processd.  See examples below.  Examples  Textual documents only     "fast"  Video documents only {     "video": "audio_video" }  Specify multiple document types {     "static": "hi_res",     "audio": true,     "video": "video_only" }  Specify only textual or audio document types {     "static": "fast",     "audio": true }  Highest quality processing for all media types     "all"

metadata.title: Metadata
metadata.description: Metadata for the document. Keys must be strings. Values may be strings, numbers, booleans, or lists of strings. Numbers may be integers or floating point and will be converted to 64 bit floating point. 1000 total values are allowed. Each item in an array counts towards the total. The following keys are reserved for internal use: `document_id`, `document_type`, `document_source`, `document_name`, `document_uploaded_at`, `start_time`, `end_time`.

file.title: File
file.description:
The binary file to upload, extract, and index for retrieval. The following file types are supported: Plain Text: `.eml` `.html` `.json` `.md` `.msg` `.rst` `.rtf` `.txt` `.xml`
Images: `.png` `.webp` `.jpg` `.jpeg` `.tiff` `.bmp` `.heic`
Documents: `.csv` `.doc` `.docx` `.epub` `.epub+zip` `.odt` `.pdf` `.ppt` `.pptx` `.tsv` `.xlsx` `.xls`. PDF files over 2000 pages are not supported in hi_res mode.

external_id.title: External Id
external_id.description: An optional identifier for the document. A common value might be an id in an external system or the URL where the source file may be found.

partition.title: Partition
partition.description: An optional partition identifier. Documents can be scoped to a partition. Partitions must be lowercase alphanumeric and may only include the special characters `_` and `-`.  A partition is created any time a document is created.

name.title: Name
name.description: An optional name for the document. If set, the document will have this name. Otherwise it will default to the file's name.

mode.title: Mode
mode.description: Partition strategy for the document. Different strategies exist for textual, audio and video file types and you can set the strategy you want for  each file type, or just for textual types.  For textual documents the options are `'hi_res'` or `'fast'`. When set to `'hi_res'`, images and tables will be extracted from the document. `'fast'` will only extract text. `'fast'` may be up to 20x faster than `'hi_res'`. `hi_res` is only applicable for Word documents, PDFs, Images, and PowerPoints. Images will always be processed in `hi_res`. If `hi_res` is set for an unsupported document type, it will be processed and billed in `fast` mode.  For audio files, the options are true or false. True if you want to process audio, false otherwise.          For video files, the options are `'audio_only'`, `'video_only'`, `'audio_video'`. `'audio_only'` will extract just the audio part of the video. `'video_only'` will similarly just extract the video part, ignoring audio. `'audio_video'` will extract both audio and video.  To process all media types at the highest quality, use `'all'`.  When you specify audio or video stategies, the format must be a JSON object. In this case, textual documents are denoted by the key "static". If you omit a key, that document type won't be processd.  See examples below.  Examples  Textual documents only     "fast"  Video documents only {     "video": "audio_video" }  Specify multiple document types {     "static": "hi_res",     "audio": true,     "video": "video_only" }  Specify only textual or audio document types {     "static": "fast",     "audio": true }  Highest quality processing for all media types     "all"

file.title: File
file.description:
The binary file to upload, extract, and index for retrieval. The following file types are supported: Plain Text: `.eml` `.html` `.json` `.md` `.msg` `.rst` `.rtf` `.txt` `.xml`
Images: `.png` `.webp` `.jpg` `.jpeg` `.tiff` `.bmp` `.heic`
Documents: `.csv` `.doc` `.docx` `.epub` `.epub+zip` `.odt` `.pdf` `.ppt` `.pptx` `.tsv` `.xlsx` `.xls`. PDF files over 2000 pages are not supported in hi_res mode.

code_issue.title: Code Issue
code_issue.description: The issue that the code was written to solve.

code_result.title: Code Result
code_result.description: The result of the code that was executed.

id.title: Id
id.description: The unique ID of the code interpreter tool call.

code.description: The code executed by the code interpreter.

container_id.description: The ID of the container used to run the code.

outputs.title: Outputs
outputs.description: The outputs generated by the code interpreter, such as logs or images.

logs.title: Logs
logs.description: The logs output from the code interpreter.

code_issue.title: Code Issue
code_issue.description: The natural language description of the code issue you need to solve.

code.title: Code
code.description: The code you generated to solve the code issue.

code_result.title: Code Result
code_result.description: The result of the code you generated after executing it.

metadata.title: Metadata
metadata.description: Metadata for the document. Keys must be strings. Values may be strings, numbers, booleans, or lists of strings. Numbers may be integers or floating point and will be converted to 64 bit floating point. 1000 total values are allowed. Each item in an array counts towards the total. The following keys are reserved for internal use: `document_id`, `document_type`, `document_source`, `document_name`, `document_uploaded_at`, `start_time`, `end_time`.

page_limit.title: Page Limit
page_limit.description: The maximum number of pages a connection will sync. The connection will be disabled after this limit is reached. Some in process documents may continue processing. Remove the limit by setting to `null`.

page_limit.title: Page Limit
page_limit.description: The maximum number of pages a connection will sync. The connection will be disabled after this limit is reached. Some in process documents may continue processing. Remove the limit by setting to `null`.

The following keys are reserved for internal use: `document_id`, `document_type`, `document_source`, `document_name`, `document_uploaded_at`, `start_time`, `end_time`.

The following keys are reserved for internal use: `document_id`, `document_type`, `document_source`, `document_name`, `document_uploaded_at`, `start_time`, `end_time`.

Different strategies exist for textual, audio and video file types and you can set the strategy you want for  each file type, or just for textual types.  For textual documents the options are `'hi_res'` or `'fast'`. When set to `'hi_res'`, images and tables will be extracted from the document. `'fast'` will only extract text. `'fast'` may be up to 20x faster than `'hi_res'`. `hi_res` is only applicable for Word documents, PDFs, Images, and PowerPoints. True if you want to process audio, false otherwise.          For video files, the options are `'audio_only'`, `'video_only'`, `'audio_video'`. `'audio_only'` will extract just the audio part of the video. `'video_only'` will similarly just extract the video part, ignoring audio. `'audio_video'` will extract both audio and video.  To process all media types at the highest quality, use `'all'`.  When you specify audio or video stategies, the format must be a JSON object. In this case, textual documents are denoted by the key "static". If you omit a key, that document type won't be processd.  See examples below.  Examples  Textual documents only     "fast"  Video documents only {     "video": "audio_video" }  Specify multiple document types {     "static": "hi_res",     "audio": true,     "video": "video_only" }  Specify only textual or audio document types {     "static": "fast",     "audio": true }  Highest quality processing for all media types     "all"

external_id.title: External Id
external_id.description: An optional identifier for the document. A common value might be an id in an external system or the URL where the source file may be found.

partition.title: Partition
partition.description: An optional partition identifier. Documents can be scoped to a partition. Partitions must be lowercase alphanumeric and may only include the special characters `_` and `-`.  A partition is created any time a document is created.

url.title: Url
url.description: Url of the file to download. Must be publicly accessible and HTTP or HTTPS scheme.

name.title: Name
name.description: An optional name for the document. If set, the document will have this name. Otherwise it will default to the current timestamp.

metadata.title: Metadata
metadata.description: Metadata for the document. Keys must be strings. Values may be strings, numbers, booleans, or lists of strings. Numbers may be integers or floating point and will be converted to 64 bit floating point. 1000 total values are allowed. Each item in an array counts towards the total. The following keys are reserved for internal use: `document_id`, `document_type`, `document_source`, `document_name`, `document_uploaded_at`, `start_time`, `end_time`.

external_id.title: External Id
external_id.description: An optional identifier for the document. A common value might be an id in an external system or the URL where the source file may be found.

partition.title: Partition
partition.description: An optional partition identifier. Documents can be scoped to a partition. Partitions must be lowercase alphanumeric and may only include the special characters `_` and `-`.  A partition is created any time a document is created.

data.title: Data
data.description: Document data in a text or JSON format.

name.title: Name
name.description: The unique name of your authenticator, used to identify it and distinguish it from others. This name must be unique. Attempting to reuse the same name will result in an error.

name.title: Name
name.description: The name of the instruction. Must be unique.

active.title: Active
active.description: Whether the instruction is active. Active instructions are applied to documents when they're created or when their file is updated.

scope.title: Scope
scope.description: The scope of the instruction. Determines whether the instruction is applied to the entire document or to each chunk of the document. Options are `'document'` or `'chunk'`. Generally `'document'` should be used when analyzing the full document is desired, such as when generating a summary or determining sentiment, and `'chunk'` should be used when a fine grained search over a document is desired.

prompt.title: Prompt
prompt.description: A natural language instruction which will be applied to documents as they are created and updated. The results of the `instruction_prompt` will be stored as an `entity` in the schema defined by the `entity_schema` parameter.
examples: Find all pizzas described in the text.

entity_schema.description: The JSON schema definition of the entity generated by an instruction. The schema must define an `object` at its root. If the instruction is expected to generate multiple items, the root object should have a key which defines an array of the expected items. An instruction which generates multiple emails may be expressed as `{"type": "object", "properties": {"emails": { "type": "array", "items": { "type": "string"}}}}`. Simple values may be expressed as an object with a single key. For example, a summary instruction may generate a single string value. The schema might be `{"type": "object", "properties": { "summary": { "type": "string"}}}`.

filter.title: Filter
filter.description: An optional metadata filter that is matched against document metadata during update and creation. The instruction will only be applied to documents with metadata matching the filter.  The following filter operators are supported: $eq - Equal to (number, string, boolean), $ne - Not equal to (number, string, boolean), $gt - Greater than (number), $gte - Greater than or equal to (number), $lt - Less than (number), $lte - Less than or equal to (number), $in - In array (string or number), $nin - Not in array (string or number). The operators can be combined with AND and OR. Read [Metadata & Filters guide](https://docs.ragie.ai/docs/metadata-filters) for more details and examples.

partition.title: Partition
partition.description: An optional partition identifier. Instructions can be scoped to a partition. An instruction that defines a partition will only be executed for documents in that partition.

pages_hosted_limit_monthly.title: Pages Hosted Limit Monthly
pages_hosted_limit_monthly.description: Monthly limit of hosted pages added in the current month in the partition.

pages_processed_limit_monthly.title: Pages Processed Limit Monthly
pages_processed_limit_monthly.description: Monthly limit, in pages, for processed documents in the partition.

pages_hosted_limit_max.title: Pages Hosted Limit Max
pages_hosted_limit_max.description: Maximum limit, in pages, for hosted documents in the partition.

pages_processed_limit_max.title: Pages Processed Limit Max
pages_processed_limit_max.description: Maximum limit, in pages, for processed documents in the partition.

audio_processed_limit_monthly.title: Audio Processed Limit Monthly
audio_processed_limit_monthly.description: Monthly limit, in minutes, for audio processing in the partition.

audio_processed_limit_max.title: Audio Processed Limit Max
audio_processed_limit_max.description: Maximum limit, in minutes, for audio processing in the partition.

video_processed_limit_monthly.title: Video Processed Limit Monthly
video_processed_limit_monthly.description: Monthly limit, in minutes, for video processing in the partition.

video_processed_limit_max.title: Video Processed Limit Max
video_processed_limit_max.description: Maximum limit, in minutes, for video processing in the partition.

media_streamed_limit_monthly.title: Media Streamed Limit Monthly
media_streamed_limit_monthly.description: Monthly limit, in MBs, for media streamed from the partition.

media_streamed_limit_max.title: Media Streamed Limit Max
media_streamed_limit_max.description: Maximum limit, in MBs, for media streamed from the partition.

media_hosted_limit_monthly.title: Media Hosted Limit Monthly
media_hosted_limit_monthly.description: Monthly limit, in MBs, for media hosted in the partition.

media_hosted_limit_max.title: Media Hosted Limit Max
media_hosted_limit_max.description: Maximum limit, in MBs, for media hosted in the partition.

modality_data.title: Modality Data
modality_data.description: Additional data specific to the modality of the chunk's source file, such as word level timestamps for chunks extracted from audio files.

metadata.title: Metadata
metadata.description: The full document metadata inclusive of the update.

instruction_id.title: Instruction Id
instruction_id.description: The ID of the instruction which generated the entity.

document_id.title: Document Id
document_id.description: The ID of the document which the entity was produced from.

data.description: The entity data generated by the instruction.

other_resolved_question_ids.title: Other Resolved Question Ids
other_resolved_question_ids.description: A list of questions ids that are no longer relevant to the current answer referenced by their IDs.

queries.title: Queries
queries.description: The queries used to search for files.

results.title: Results
results.description: The results of the file search tool call.

file_id.title: File Id
file_id.description: The unique ID of the document.

score.title: Score
score.description: The relevance score of the chunk - a value between 0 and 1.

text.title: Text
text.description: The text content of the chunk.

text.title: Text
text.description: The final answer to the question.

evidence.title: Evidence
evidence.description: The evidence used to derive the answer.

steps.title: Steps
steps.description: The steps that led to the answer.

active.title: Active

Generally `'document'` should be used when analyzing the full document is desired, such as when generating a summary or determining sentiment, and `'chunk'` should be used when a fine grained search over a document is desired.

examples: Find all pizzas described in the text.

If the instruction is expected to generate multiple items, the root object should have a key which defines an array of the expected items. An instruction which generates multiple emails may be expressed as `{"type": "object", "properties": {"emails": { "type": "array", "items": { "type": "string"}}}}`. Simple values may be expressed as an object with a single key. For example, a summary instruction may generate a single string value. The schema might be `{"type": "object", "properties": { "summary": { "type": "string"}}}`.

The instruction will only be applied to documents with metadata matching the filter.  The following filter operators are supported: $eq - Equal to (number, string, boolean), $ne - Not equal to (number, string, boolean), $gt - Greater than (number), $gte - Greater than or equal to (number), $lt - Less than (number), $lte - Less than or equal to (number), $in - In array (string or number), $nin - Not in array (string or number). The operators can be combined with AND and OR. Read [Metadata & Filters guide](https://docs.ragie.ai/docs/metadata-filters) for more details and examples.

partition.title: Partition
partition.description: An optional partition identifier. Instructions can be scoped to a partition. An instruction that defines a partition will only be executed for documents in that partition.

user_email.title: User Email
user_email.description: The email of the Intercom account this is for

name.title: Name
name.description: The unique name of your authenticator, used to identify it and distinguish it from others. This name must be unique. Attempting to reuse the same name will result in an error.

source_type.description: The type of connector you want to create, such as google_drive, notion, hubspot, etc.

metadata.title: Metadata
metadata.description: Metadata for the document. Keys must be strings. Values may be strings, numbers, booleans, or lists of strings. Numbers may be integers or floating point and will be converted to 64 bit floating point. 1000 total values are allowed. Each item in an array counts towards the total. The following keys are reserved for internal use: `document_id`, `document_type`, `document_source`, `document_name`, `document_uploaded_at`, `start_time`, `end_time`.

theme.title: Theme
theme.description: Sets the theme of the Ragie Web UI when the user lands there. Can be light, dark, or system to use whatever the system value is. If omitted, system is used.

page_limit.title: Page Limit
page_limit.description: The maximum number of pages a connection will sync. The connection will be disabled after this limit is reached. Some in progress documents may continue processing after the limit is reached. The limit will be enforced at the start of the next document sync. Remove the limit by setting to null.

metadata.title: Metadata
metadata.description: The metadata to update on the document. Performs a partial update of the document's metadata. Keys must be strings. Values may be strings, numbers, booleans, or lists of strings. Numbers may be integers or floating point and will be converted to 64 bit floating point. Keys set to `null` are deleted. 1000 total values are allowed, inclusive of existing metadata. Each item in an array counts towards the total. The following keys are reserved for internal use: `document_id`, `document_type`, `document_source`, `document_name`, `document_uploaded_at`. If the document is managed by a connection, this operation will extend a metadata overlay which is applied to the document any time the connection syncs the document.

examples.classified: null (setting null deletes key from metadata)
examples.title: declassified report

async.title: Async
async.description: Whether to run the metadata update asynchronously. If true, the metadata update will be run in the background and the response will be 202. If false, the metadata update will be run synchronously and the response will be 200.

questions_to_answer.title: Questions To Answer
questions_to_answer.description: The questions that need to be answered to answer the original question.

metadata.title: Metadata
metadata.description: Metadata for the document. Keys must be strings. Values may be strings, numbers, booleans, or lists of strings. Numbers may be integers or floating point and will be converted to 64 bit floating point. 1000 total values are allowed. Each item in an array counts towards the total. The following keys are reserved for internal use: `document_id`, `document_type`, `document_source`, `document_name`, `document_uploaded_at`, `start_time`, `end_time`.

user_email.title: User Email
user_email.description: The email the API key is associated with

id.title: Id
id.description: The chunk id of the evidence.

index.title: Index
index.description: The index of the chunk in the document.

document_id.title: Document Id
document_id.description: The document id of the document containing the chunk being used as evidence.

document_name.title: Document Name
document_name.description: The name of the document that contains the chunk being used as evidence.

metadata.title: Metadata
metadata.description: The metadata of the chunk being used as evidence.

document_metadata.title: Document Metadata
document_metadata.description: The metadata of the document that contains the evidence.

id.title: Id
id.description: The unique ID of the reasoning output.

encrypted_content.title: Encrypted Content
encrypted_content.description: The encrypted content of the reasoning output.

input.title: Input
input.description: The text used to generate the response. Generally a question or a query.

instructions.title: Instructions
instructions.description: The instructions inserted in the prompt. For this agent, the instructions are injected during search related steps.

tools.title: Tools
tools.description: The tools available to the agent. Currently the only tool is retrieve. The `default` partition is used by default unless an other partition is specified.

model.title: Model
model.description: The model to use for the agent. Currently the only model is deep-search.

reasoning.description: The reasoning to use for the agent. The default effort level is medium.

query.title: Query
query.description: The query to search with when retrieving document chunks.
examples: What is the best pizza place in SF?

top_k.title: Top K
top_k.description: The maximum number of chunks to return. Defaults to 8.

filter.title: Filter
filter.description: The metadata search filter on documents. Returns chunks only from documents which match the filter. The following filter operators are supported: $eq - Equal to (number, string, boolean), $ne - Not equal to (number, string, boolean), $gt - Greater than (number), $gte - Greater than or equal to (number), $lt - Less than (number), $lte - Less than or equal to (number), $in - In array (string or number), $nin - Not in array (string or number). The operators can be combined with AND and OR. Read [Metadata & Filters guide](https://docs.ragie.ai/docs/metadata-filters) for more details and examples.

rerank.title: Rerank
rerank.description: Reranks the chunks for semantic relevancy post cosine similarity. Will be slower but returns a subset of highly relevant chunks. Best for reducing hallucinations and improving accuracy for LLM generation.

max_chunks_per_document.title: Max Chunks Per Document
max_chunks_per_document.description: Maximum number of chunks to retrieve per document. Use this to increase the number of documents the final chunks are retrieved from. This feature is in beta and may change in the future.

partition.title: Partition
partition.description: The partition to scope a retrieval to. If omitted, the retrieval will be scoped to the default partition, which includes any documents that have not been created in a partition.

recency_bias.title: Recency Bias
recency_bias.description: Enables recency bias which will favor more recent documents vs older documents. https://docs.ragie.ai/docs/retrievals-recency-bias

search.description: The search request to be made.
The search request to be made.

search_log.title: Search Log
search_log.description: A log of the search results you found.

partial_answer.description: The a potential partial answer when a full answer was not possible.

mode.title: Mode
mode.description: Partition strategy for the document. Different strategies exist for textual, audio and video file types and you can set the strategy you want for  each file type, or just for textual types.  For textual documents the options are `'hi_res'` or `'fast'`. When set to `'hi_res'`, images and tables will be extracted from the document. `'fast'` will only extract text. `'fast'` may be up to 20x faster than `'hi_res'`. `hi_res` is only applicable for Word documents, PDFs, Images, and PowerPoints. Images will always be processed in `hi_res`. If `hi_res` is set for an unsupported document type, it will be processed and billed in `fast` mode.  For audio files, the options are true or false. True if you want to process audio, false otherwise.          For video files, the options are `'audio_only'`, `'video_only'`, `'audio_video'`. `'audio_only'` will extract just the audio part of the video. `'video_only'` will similarly just extract the video part, ignoring audio. `'audio_video'` will extract both audio and video.  To process all media types at the highest quality, use `'all'`.  When you specify audio or video stategies, the format must be a JSON object. In this case, textual documents are denoted by the key "static". If you omit a key, that document type won't be processd.  See examples below.  Examples  Textual documents only     "fast"  Video documents only {     "video": "audio_video" }  Specify multiple document types {     "static": "hi_res",     "audio": true,     "video": "video_only" }  Specify only textual or audio document types {     "static": "fast",     "audio": true }  Highest quality processing for all media types     "all"

url.title: Url
url.description: Url of the file to download. Must be publicly accessible and HTTP or HTTPS scheme.

data.title: Data
data.description: Document data in a text or JSON format.

active.title: Active
active.description: Whether the instruction is active. Active instructions are applied to documents when they're created or when their file is updated.

mode.title: Mode
mode.description: Partition strategy for the document. Different strategies exist for textual, audio and video file types and you can set the strategy you want for  each file type, or just for textual types.  For textual documents the options are `'hi_res'` or `'fast'`. When set to `'hi_res'`, images and tables will be extracted from the document. `'fast'` will only extract text. `'fast'` may be up to 20x faster than `'hi_res'`. `hi_res` is only applicable for Word documents, PDFs, Images, and PowerPoints. Images will always be processed in `hi_res`. If `hi_res` is set for an unsupported document type, it will be processed and billed in `fast` mode.  For audio files, the options are true or false. True if you want to process audio, false otherwise.          For video files, the options are `'audio_only'`, `'video_only'`, `'audio_video'`. `'audio_only'` will extract just the audio part of the video. `'video_only'` will similarly just extract the video part, ignoring audio. `'audio_video'` will extract both audio and video.  To process all media types at the highest quality, use `'all'`.  When you specify audio or video stategies, the format must be a JSON object. In this case, textual documents are denoted by the key "static". If you omit a key, that document type won't be processd.  See examples below.  Examples  Textual documents only     "fast"  Video documents only {     "video": "audio_video" }  Specify multiple document types {     "static": "hi_res",     "audio": true,     "video": "video_only" }  Specify only textual or audio document types {     "static": "fast",     "audio": true }  Highest quality processing for all media types     "all"

metadata.title: Metadata
metadata.description: Metadata for the document. Keys must be strings. Values may be strings, numbers, booleans, or lists of strings. Numbers may be integers or floating point and will be converted to 64 bit floating point. 1000 total values are allowed. Each item in an array counts towards the total. The following keys are reserved for internal use: `document_id`, `document_type`, `document_source`, `document_name`, `document_uploaded_at`, `start_time`, `end_time`.

file.title: File
file.description:
The binary file to upload, extract, and index for retrieval. The following file types are supported: Plain Text: `.eml` `.html` `.json` `.md` `.msg` `.rst` `.rtf` `.txt` `.xml`
Images: `.png` `.webp` `.jpg` `.jpeg` `.tiff` `.bmp` `.heic`
Documents: `.csv` `.doc` `.docx` `.epub` `.epub+zip` `.odt` `.pdf` `.ppt` `.pptx` `.tsv` `.xlsx` `.xls`. PDF files over 2000 pages are not supported in hi_res mode.

external_id.title: External Id
external_id.description: An optional identifier for the document. A common value might be an id in an external system or the URL where the source file may be found.

name.title: Name
name.description: An optional name for the document. If set, the document will have this name. Otherwise it will default to the file's name.

partition.title: Partition
partition.description: An optional partition identifier. Documents can be scoped to a partition. Partitions must be lowercase alphanumeric and may only include the special characters `_` and `-`.  A partition is created any time a document is created.

mode.title: Mode
mode.description: Partition strategy for the document. Different strategies exist for textual, audio and video file types and you can set the strategy you want for  each file type, or just for textual types.  For textual documents the options are `'hi_res'` or `'fast'`. When set to `'hi_res'`, images and tables will be extracted from the document. `'fast'` will only extract text. `'fast'` may be up to 20x faster than `'hi_res'`. `hi_res` is only applicable for Word documents, PDFs, Images, and PowerPoints. Images will always be processed in `hi_res`. If `hi_res` is set for an unsupported document type, it will be processed and billed in `fast` mode.  For audio files, the options are true or false. True if you want to process audio, false otherwise.          For video files, the options are `'audio_only'`, `'video_only'`, `'audio_video'`. `'audio_only'` will extract just the audio part of the video. `'video_only'` will similarly just extract the video part, ignoring audio. `'audio_video'` will extract both audio and video.  To process all media types at the highest quality, use `'all'`.  When you specify audio or video stategies, the format must be a JSON object. In this case, textual documents are denoted by the key "static". If you omit a key, that document type won't be processd.  See examples below.  Examples  Textual documents only     "fast"  Video documents only {     "video": "audio_video" }  Specify multiple document types {     "static": "hi_res",     "audio": true,     "video": "video_only" }  Specify only textual or audio document types {     "static": "fast",     "audio": true }  Highest quality processing for all media types     "all"

file.description:
The binary file to upload, extract, and index for retrieval. The following file types are supported: Plain Text: `.eml` `.html` `.json` `.md` `.msg` `.rst` `.rtf` `.txt` `.xml`
Images: `.png` `.webp` `.jpg` `.jpeg` `.tiff` `.bmp` `.heic`
Documents: `.csv` `.doc` `.docx` `.epub` `.epub+zip` `.odt` `.pdf` `.ppt` `.pptx` `.tsv` `.xlsx` `.xls`. PDF files over 2000 pages are not supported in hi_res mode.
